LJava
Class Constraint

java.lang.Object
  LJava.Constraint
All Implemented Interfaces:
Lazy<LJMap>, LJ.QueryParameter
public class Constraint
extends java.lang.Object
implements LJ.QueryParameter, Lazy<LJMap>

Author:
Tzali Maimon Constraint is the class that is responsible for queries in LJ.

When you a query using LJ's logic operators a tree is built within a constraint object and is managed from here.

Like any other class in LJ Constraint is also thread-safe.

Constraint can be activated through the Lazy interface.

Method Detail

satisfy

public boolean satisfy(LJMap map)
Checks if the first value of each variable in the LJMap are legal according to this constraint.

Parameters:
map - - LJMap containing the required restrictions to check.
Returns:
true if all values are legal.

satisfy

public boolean satisfy(Variable[] vs,
                       java.lang.Object[] os)
Checks to see if the Variables in vs can be swapped by the corresponding values in os within the constraint legally.

Parameters:
vs - - a variables array
os - - an objects array
Returns:
true if after swapping the constraint is still satisfied.

satisfy

Parameters:
map - - a hash map
Returns:
- satisfy(LJMap)

satisfy

public boolean satisfy(java.lang.Object... pairs)
Divides the given arguments into pairs of Variable, Object and returns true if the constraint is satisfied after swapping each variable within it with the corresponding object.

EXAMPLE: satisfy(x,1,y,"A",z, new Relation("try it");

NOTE: a wrong format in the argument will cause the method to return false as it's obvious that the constraint isn't satisfied in such a case.

Parameters:
pairs - - arguments in pairs
Returns:
true if after swapping the constraint is still satisfied.

asRelation

public Relation asRelation()
returns this constraint as a relation if it can be represented as such. It means that the constraint only holds a single restriction and it is that the contained relation needs to be satisfied.

Returns:

public Constraint replaceVariable(Variable v,
                                  java.lang.Object o)
replace the variable v with the object o within the constraint and returning a new constraint (this constraint won't change).

o - - a target object

- a new constraint.

base

public java.lang.Object base()
Specified by:
base in interface Lazy<LJMap>
Returns:
the object on which the lazy interface is running, so for a lazy that was created on permutations, for example, it will return the Group object that is used through the evaluation.

for more info read at logicjava.wordpress.com
